vote.title: Mommy, Daddy and Me
vote.description: Whereas, Research documents the importance of building connection and attachment between mother and child to support the wellness of both; Whereas, We know that nationally nearly one third of teen girls who have dropped out of high school cite early pregnancy or parenthood as the key reason; Whereas, Nearly 40 percent of teen mothers finish high school and less than 2 percent of teen mothers finish college by age 30; Whereas, The Los Angeles Unified School District must work intentionally to retain teen parents as they navigate both parenthood and their academic success; and Whereas, This resolution aims to create an ongoing culture of institutional support for teen parents within the District; now, therefore, be it Resolved, That the Governing Board of the Los Angeles Unified School District directs the Superintendent to develop a plan, informed by student parents, that creates a more robust and comprehensive student maternity support system, and an ideal school setting for student parents that includes the following components: ●	Schools have space for daycare, through exploring the need for programs and opportunities to partner with local community based organizations; ●	Explore expansion of our infant centers, as part of the District’s universal preschool efforts, to serve more parenting students;●	Designed “lactation area” and lactation support, such as protected time to breastfeed, express milk, or address other infant feeding needs during the school day;●	Funding for a full-time position, or at minimum provide specialized trainings to an existing staff person or leveraging community partners with expertise in this area, ensuring there is a person on campus focused on providing supports to student parents in accessing prenatal care, finding parental education, child care and supportive resources, and creating a curriculum for all students on prenatal care and child development;●	Explore partnerships to ensure pregnant and parenting students have access to home visiting programs;●	Access to resources for students on comprehensive sexual health, including access to contraceptives;●	Explore opportunities to incentivize parents in completing their diploma through partnerships with community based organizations and philanthropy;●	Revise District policies to allow for a parental leave of absence with no negative impact on their grades or graduation date and ensure school counselors are trained to support the unique needs of parenting students and support them in pursuing their educational goals; and●	Explore how this could be supportive of COVID relief efforts;  Resolved further, That the Los Angeles Unified School District will recognize Student Parent Awareness Month, in conjunction with recognizing Women’s History Month, annually in March, encouraging schools to celebrate student parents by creating opportunities where student parents can be embraced as parents at the same time as students, such as the ability to bring their child to school in accordance with District policy; and, be it finally Resolved, That the Board directs the Superintendent to ensure all students starting in 5th grade have access to a Sex Education curriculum embedded across multiple discussions regarding developmentally appropriate sexual health information, including access to contraceptives starting in 7th grade in accordance with Education Code, with the recognition that the Education Code allows parents to opt out of sexual health education.
